boardgame.name: Manchester
boardgame.description:
A chess variant in which spaces have a card with a picture of a chess piece drawn on it which determines the move of the player's pawns. It is played on a 6 by 6 grid; to start with only the end zones have cards on them, but each turn another (face up from a stack)is placed onto an empty space. Pawns starting from spaces without cards can only move forward or backwards and can't capture.

The game is thus partly about conventional chess and partly about constructing the board to favour yourself.

My copy was sold as a double game with Thataway, with which it shares a board and some pieces; I don't know if it has ever been sold separately.

I believe this game was originally sold as Chafts, as early as 1986. David Watts visited Cardiff to trial it.

boardgame.name: Atoms
boardgame.description:
Split molecules into smaller atoms & stalemate your opponent in this 2-player abstract game.

Equipment:

* 8x8 square board
* 11 stones per player

On the first turn White drops an atom on any cell; then players alternate placing atoms on any empty cell which is adjacent to exactly one other atom (of either color). After all atoms are placed they form one large molecule, which may split into several smaller molecules during the game.

Each atom has a valence, which is the number of atoms (of either color) adjacent to it (include diagonal). Players must now move one of their atoms to any adjacent empty cell provided that its valence in the new position is exactly the same as its valence in the old position.

Any atom which is not adjacent to an enemy atom is unstable. Immediately after each move, the players remove all unstable atoms from the board. This also occurs after Black makes his last drop.

A player wins by stalemating his opponent, (leaving him with no legal moves). A player also wins by leaving an empty board (after the removal operation); in fact this is a special case of stalemate since his opponent would have no moves at all.

R. Kraus defined two variants: Isotopes, where each atom can move any number of cells (instead of just being able to move to the adjacent cell); and Radioactive Atoms, where a stone may also commit suicide (if able to move to an isolated cell)

boardgame.name: Attraction
boardgame.description:
Equipment:

* 8x8 square board
* 8 stones for each player (16 stones in all)

Each player sets up his pieces along his side of the board.

Stones (or planets) may move in orbits around another (orthogonal) adjacent stone (the gravity center) of either color. This means that the moving stone can move to an empty cell which is orthogonally adjacent to the gravity center. This implies that isolated stones cannot move. Orbits are multiple, after one orbit, the moving stone can continue to move, if the direction of the orbit is smooth (e.g., if it began clockwise, it must continue counterclockwise, and so on...)

Another moving possibility is that if there is a 3rd planet in front of a possible orbit, the orbiting stone can move to its place and push that stone to the immediate next empty cell (in the same direction of the orbit). If that next immediate cell is not empty, the gravity push is not possible.

The first player that moves all of his stones into the initial adversary setup wins.

Bridges and Boats is a strategic war game in which the attacker is trying to get soldiers across a major river while the enemy tries to stop them.

Quoted from the 5th Column Rules Introduction:

With rules easy enough for a novice to understand, yet subtle enough to delight the expert, 5th Column adds the rules and new playing pieces to add increasing realism to Milton Bradley’s Fortress America, while maintaining the game’s ease and speed of play. 5th Column adds the ability to influence your game with unconventional tactics.

boardgame.name: Geheimnis der Detektive
boardgame.description:
A gang of robbers has stolen some valuable goods last night. This loot is still in town, but there is no relying on the police. So the players - as detectives (private eyes) - are appointed to find the loot.

The game uses a special movement system regarding the famous German pub game "Knobeln". It is all about bluffing and hunting for the best cards. Sudden events can alter the personal strategy. Each player gets 5 small (movement) sticks. Acting simultaneously with his neighbor both hide a certain number of sticks in their hands, then open their hands and count up the total amount. Players may move if both hands show different numbers of sticks and the total amount does not equal 5; if you end on a loot slide check it (value 0 - 4) & keep it. If a player lands on another player, it offers you an opportunity to steal. If the stick-count equals 5 players add a barrier, and an equal number of sticks held by each player forces them back to the starting point, and they draw an event card.

boardgame.name: Annex
boardgame.description:
The game comes with 132 letter tiles in four colors, three 'wild' tiles, and a board that consists of interlocking paths. Each player draws four tiles as his or her starting hand. An additional eight tiles are drawn and turned face-up to be used as a common pool. The pool and the players' hands are replenished as the letters are used.

Players take turns placing letters onto the paths to form words. Each word must use at least one letter already on the board and at least one letter either from the common pool or from the player's hand. Words may turn corners (move from one path onto a different one) and read forward or backward, up or down. Longer words score more than shorter words; words using letters of a single color score more than words of multiple colors. The game ends when all the paths are completed or when no one can play a letter that will form a new word.

boardgame.name: Wordsworth
boardgame.description:
This is word rummy with a few twists. Players maintain a hand of letter cards by drawing, by melding words formed by the letters, and then by discarding. Players receive points for completing their required melds, for going out, for the point values of the letters in the melded words, and for the length of the melded words.

As in Phase 10, the difficulty of the required meld increases with each round: eg, two 3-letter words in Round One; one 7-letter word in the final round.

Players receive extra points for melding words that are related to the theme of the game, which is determined by drawing a card before the start of play.

Players also receive extra points for completing a bonus word that differs in each round.

boardgame.name: La Chasse au Mammouth
boardgame.description:
La Chasse au Mammouth (=Hunt for Mammoths) was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA/Der Schwarze Peter" #88/4.

The board shows a glacier with 6 mammoth trails and several human trails crossing them. Player camps, weapon directory, and storehouses are also on the board.

Up to 2 Mammoth herds (4 at the start of the game) enter the board every turn and travel along their trails.

Each player starts with 20 tribesmen and 5 x 5 weapons of 5 different types. The well armed tribesmen go out to hunt some mammoths, which are needed to feed the population. The weapons used to kill a mammoth are removed from the game, that is they represent more a consumable arrow than an bow, that can be used all the time.

Every second turn, it is checked to see how many tribesmen can be fed (with half a mammoth per man). Men who are not fed are flipped over and all their abilities are halved for the next turn. Subsequent non-feeding will result in the elimination of the men.

While hunting mammoths is relatively easy at the start of the game, it gets harder and harder, because players must manufacture new weapons and pitfalls and thus only some of the men can be used for hunting.

The game ends, when the first player has lost all tribesmen. Winner is the player who has the most surviving men on the board at that time.

boardgame.name: Das Umzugsspiel
boardgame.description:
Das Umzugsspiel ("Change of Residence") was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA/Der schwarze Peter" #89/1.

The board shows a fictive city map with a furniture warehouse in the middle and 4 residences in each corner.

Object of the game is to move his 7 furniture pieces from the starting residence to the residence at the opposing edge of the board with the help of 1 van per player.

Movements are done by dice rolls, but 54 also included cards influence the movements heavily. Fortunately, only 26 cards must be used immediately. The remaining 28 cards give more room to avoid too much bad luck.

4 mobile road works (=obstacles) hinder the players to move where they want and the fact that loosing furniture pieces is also possible (must be replaced by picking new furnitures in the furniture warehouse) does not only make the game more interesting, it also gives the feeling of a real change of residence - with all possible frustrating experiences.

Winner of the game is the player who has moved his furnitures to the target domicile first.

boardgame.name: Flohzirkus
boardgame.description:
Flohzirkus (="flea circus") is played on a board with 12 x 12 dots in 4 alternating colours. 5 colour dice and 2 large wooden fleas per player complete the game components.

Each flea is marked with 4 colours: 1 yellow dash at the head, 1 blue dash at the tail, 1 red flea drawing on the right side and 1 green flea drawing on the left.

Each turn, a player throws the 5 dice, which enable him to make 5 moves. Yellow, blue, red and green lets a flea jump to the 4 directions as marked on the flea, white and black enables a flea to turn in place or to shift to an adjacent dot.

Object of the game is to achieve as many points as possible, which is done by jumping over as many other fleas as possible. Winner of the game is the player with the most points after a predefined number of turns, or the one who reaches a predefined number of points first.

The game reminds at Alex Randolph's game family including "Corona"(1974), "Moonstar"(1981), "Harun"(1984), "Orbit"(1993) and "Ricochet Robots"(1999). Opposite to those games, each player has his own playing pieces in "Flohzirkus", but the lack of a time limit can be a serious problem here.

boardgame.name: Moby Dicks Freunde
boardgame.description:
Moby Dicks Freunde is played on a board with 8 x 10 rhombs. Every line of the rhomb shows a number between 1 and 6. 8 dice and 8 whales are the game components.

Each player has 4 whales, who are placed on the first 4 rhomb edges to the right. Each turn, 5-8 dice are thrown. Whales can move to adjacent rhomb edges, when the die on the board corresponds to one of the die numbers.

A restriction is that the 4 whales of a player must always form a herd, that is they must always be connected to each other.

Moving the whales on the side where the opposing herd stays is allowed, but only, if they are not blocked by such moves. Thus, a certain amount of cooperative play is requested!

Winner of the game is the player whose herd reaches the opposing side of the board first.

(Karin and Reinhold Wittig are named for the copyright of the game rules. The game is by Reinhold Wittig alone, though).

boardgame.name: Atomic
boardgame.description:
A game for two that's a real blast! An abstract game with a connection element -- be the player that has the most pieces showing in your color by the end of the game.

Equipment:

* An hexagonal grid, in the shape of a hexagon, containing 61 hexes.
* Two sets of 30 double-sided hexagonal pieces:
o 12 Connectors (one line joining two opposite sides) with the opponent's 12 Alternators on the reverse side
o 12 Alternators (three lines joining three, alternating sides) with the opponent's 12 Connectors on the reverse side),
o 3 Destructors (six lines joining all sides) with the opponent's 3 Burn-outs on the reverse side)
o 3 Burn-outs (six lines joining all sides) with the opponent's 3 Destructors on the reverse side

A play consists of one of placing one marker - face-up with the colour of the player whose turn it is - on any unoccupied space on the board. The player then traces a path ('reaction') through as many pieces of the opposing colour as he can. A path is a continuous line passing from a piece of the player's colour to one of his opponent's. Once the path is established, the opponent's piece is flipped over and the piece rotated in such a way that at least one of the lines on it joins up to the path. If there are now no lines on the new piece that point to another opposing piece, or if the flipped piece is a Burn-out, the 'reaction' is over, and the player's turn ends.

The objective is for each player to have the most pieces showing his colour at the end of the game. If there are an equal number of each, the game is a draw.

boardgame.name: Official Baseball Card Game
boardgame.description:
Teams are drafted from a deck of the best players of the day. Hank Aaron, Ernie Banks, Lou Brock, Rod Carew, Roberto Clemente, Tommy Davis, Jim Fregosi, Bill Freehan, Tom Haller, Frank Howard, Reggie Jackson, Harmon Killebrew, Mickey Lolich, Juan Marichal, Willie Mays, Willie McCovey, Sam McDowell, Dennis Menke, Don Mincher, Phil Niekro, Rico Petrocelli, Boog Powell, Frank Robinson, Ron Santo, Tom Seaver, Mel Stottlemyre, and Tony Taylor are some of the players represented. Once the players have their teams each organizes a line up.

Another deck of cards represents the possible outcomes of an at bat. This deck is shuffled and one card for each player in the field is placed face down on the playing surface.

An at bat consists of rolling two six-sided dice and if the result is a two the batter has drawn a walk. Seven means a strike out. Otherwise, check for the number on the back of the batter's card. The number corresponds to a fielding position and check that fielding position of the result. An outfield result is more likely to result in a hit than an infield result. any card used is replaced from the top card of the draw pile and the deck is reshuffled when depleted. All standard rules of baseball apply.

The game is a prized collectible. Milton Bradley also released an Official Baseball board game at about the same time.

boardgame.name: Commodity
boardgame.description:
Commodity is a buying and selling game that is not meant to simulate real life, although there are some similarities.

Ages 12 and up can play Commodity. Younger children can play with an adult and may even win!

The object of Commodity is:

1. To make money by buying and selling.
2. To pay off all debts.
3. To manage your company to gain wealth.

Commodity can be played to different limits which the players can set at the beginning of (or during) the game. For example, an average game would be set at $1,000,000, a shorter game at $500,000 and a longer game at $2,000,000.

To win Commodity, a player must:

1. Be debt free.
2. Reach the limit set by the players.
3. Declare a win.

In order to declare a win, a player must state, ON HIS TURN, that he has met or gone beyond the set limit. This player then completes his turn. The other players now have one more turn to try and defeat the declaring player. The player with the most money at the end wins. A player DOES NOT have to declare a win until he chooses to do so.

See www.markallangames.com for more information.

The first to collect a complete set and lay them down shouts "Fleet Street" and scores the points for that set. The cards are reshuffled and dealt again. Winner is the first to reach 250 points.
Each of the 48 newspapers/magazines have their own individual depiction of the front page - the magazines are especially colorful.

boardgame.name: Barrier
boardgame.description:
This game is played on an empty NxN square board (such as a 7x7 board).

Each player drops his stone on an empty cell. On each turn, each player must move his stone. The stone moves similar to a chess Knight, but in two steps rather than one. First it moves one (two) cell(s) in one direction, then two (one) cell(s) orthogonally (hence each player has two moves per turn). All positions moved to or jumped over turn into an impenetrable barrier for both players (i.e., they cannot be moved into or jumped over).

Whoever leaves his opponent with no move first wins.

boardgame.name: Tumble-Numbers
boardgame.description:
Tumble-Numbers is an interesting dice game similar to Shut the Box except that instead of a box with fixed numbers (1 to 9), it uses a set of ten red six-sided dice with non-standard numbers (as high as 10 and including blanks) to generate the numbers that have to be eliminated by rolling a pair of ordinary green six-sided dice.

The blanks can be used to represent any positive number but must always be removed together with another red die not showing a blank.

A player keeps on rolling the green dice and removing red dice that add up to the total on the green dice at each turn. When the player cannot do this, they take the sum on the remaining red dice as their penalty score (blanks count 20 points). When the player manages to get rid of all red dice, they subtract 10 points.

When a player reaches 100 points or more, he/she has to drop out. The last surviving player is the winner.

boardgame.name: Wealth of Nations
boardgame.description:
In Wealth of Nations, you take on the role of a national leader. Your goal is to take your nation from humble beginnings to the status of a world economic superpower. You achieve this by building Industries, which allows you to produce Commodities. There are six types of Industry tiles: Farms, Generators, Academies, Mines, Factories, and Banks. Each Industry is capable of producing a certain type of Commodity: Food, Energy, Labor, Ore, and Capital (respectively).

Each Commodity has one or more uses in the game. For example, Food is required to "feed" your Industries when they produce, while Capital is used to build certain types of Industries. As you build Industries, you create ever larger Industrial Blocs. The larger a Bloc is, the greater your return on investment when the Bloc produces Commodities.

The main focus of the game is trade. Because it is economically unfeasible to produce every Commodity you need, you must engage in trade to get the Commodities that you require. Each Commodity has a trade value influenced by the Markets.

There is one Market for each type of Commodity. If you can't gain a Commodity that you need by trading with your fellow players, you must buy it from the Market. Buying a Commodity from the Market increases its price, reflecting increased demand. Similarly, there are times when you can't unload your surplus Commodities because your fellow players have no need for them. If you wish to earn money from these Commodities, you must sell them to the Market. Selling a Commodity to the Market decreases its price, reflecting increased supply.

As you build new Industries and earn more money, you acquire Victory Points. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game, i.e., the player with the most valuable combination of Industries and money, is the winner.

How will you build your Nation?

boardgame.name: Scrimmage
boardgame.description:
Scrimmage was invented by Chuck Eskridge, and David Williams. It is a football game in which one side controls the offense and the other controls the defense. Movement is accomplished by dice rolls, with slower players have lower maximum movement capability. Each side has pieces (players) of varying strength and speed. Any player can tackle any other player, but only players of equal or greater strength can block opposing players. The offense sets up, and then the defense, with a twist: the defense does not know whether the offense is running a passing play or a running play. (The choice is disclosed after the play starts.) If it is a passing play, the pass can be thrown to a designated grid but only after the play has had time to develop. If a play breaks down, the offensive player draws a card to determine whether he can recover.

The passing mechanism works wonderfully: the offense places two men downfield in one of several grids, and secretly chooses a card identifying the grid to which the pass will be made. Each team then moves players (including the potential receivers) with the roll of the dice. When the pass is made, the offense chooses which square in the grid the pass will go to. The choice of squares determines how easy it is for the receiver and the defensive back(s) to get to the square to which the pass is made: if the receiver gets to the square and the back does not, the pass is complete. If the back gets to the square and the receiver does not, the pass is intercepted. If both get to the square, the pass is incomplete.

The running game and the pass rush depend on the the success of the blockers and the defensive line. There is luck in the dice rolls, of course, but the luck evens out over the course of the game and a good play can survive a little bad luck. Card drawing can also be important. Sometimes tacklers reach the ball carrier but fail to make the tackle, or make the tackle and force a fumble, which can be recovered by either the offense of defense.

This is one of the few games non-simulation football games (i.e., not strat-o-matic football or its cousins) that really feels like you are playing football. You choose your play in advance, and, like real football, sometimes it works as planned, sometimes it fails, and sometimes you have to improvise during the course of the play.

Only about 800 copies of the game were sold, primarily in game stores in the South. Two versions were created, the original version and a second version that included an optional "monster man" with good speed and power.

This game is not to be confused with the SPI game of the same name-- and almost the same year.

boardgame.description:
Be the best Barista by trying to brew the perfect cup of coffee. But, be careful. You may just spill your masterpiece.
In Barista, players compete to be the first to brew a customer's specialty coffee drink, as ordered. The player who brews the cup first, or comes closest to it, will earn tips toward victory as the best Barista.
Each round, 4 dice are rolled, each representing one aspect of the specialty coffee to be brewed. The game comes with 56 cards, 4 special dice, a coffee mug dice cup/tip jar, 20 tokens (tips), a special token bag, and rules that could be written a bit better. All in all, a good experience for specialty coffee fans everywhere.

boardgame.name: MonPoc
Monsterpocalypse
Monsterpocalypse D.M.Z.(Dangerous Monster Zone)
boardgame.description:
Monsterpocalypse brings the kaiju (giant monster) genre to the tabletop in the form of an exciting and highly strategic war game.

Designed by Matt Wilson (I), the award winning creator of Warmachine and Hordes, Monsterpocalypse utilises the critically acclaimed abilities of Privateer Press as a leading miniatures manufacturer to enter a new category of product with a property that will appeal to a world-wide fan base of all ages.

The players take the role of different factions (dinosaurs, robots, aliens, monsters and so on) fighting with one large (Godzilla size) creature combined with a steady flow of smaller units to support it. The battlefield is a cityscape (poster map) with building models integral to the game's strategy and gameplay. The game uses dice pools of custom dice that are used for both attacking and taking actions, leading to an ebb and flow between monster and unit turns. The goal for both players is to eliminate the monster on the opposing side.

Monsterpocalypse launched as a CMG in Fall 2008 with the 'Rise' block which consisted of a base set ('Rise') and two expansion sets ('I Chomp NY' and 'All Your Base'), both of which were released in 2009. The second block was released in Fall 2009 with the base set ('Now') and an expansion set ('Big in Japan') in 2010. The last expansion for the 'Now' block has still not been released as of 2015.

Each set contains large-scale monsters, as well as smaller support units and interactive buildings. Figures were sold in semi-randomized starter packs and randomized booster packs, with limited figures available only through promotional events.

In 2010 Privateer Press released the Monsterpocalypse 2 Player Battle Box, a semi-randomised set which contained everything 2 players needed to dive right into the game, including two full factions and a complete set of buildings (all from Set 1 'Rise'). In 2011 they also released Monsterpocalypse Dangerous Monster Zone or Monsterpocalypse DMZ for short. These worked as expansion packs for the 2 Player Battle Box, each containing completely fixed, faction specific sets of Set 2 'I Chomp NY' and 3 'All Your Base' miniatures. By buying the DMZs for the factions you got in your initial battle box you would have 2 complete factions and a full set of buildings from the 'Rise' block, making Monsterpocalypse much more accessible for newer players in a more non-collectible format.

The game includes card packs for various genres of music including classical and religious hymns.

boardgame.name: Gensou no Utage
Rumbling Spell Orchestra
幻想ノ宴
boardgame.description:
Rumbling Spell Orchestra is a CCG based on the "Touhou Project" series of Japanese shoot-em-up games. They're what the Japanese call "danmaku" games, literally "bullet hell," a genre known for it's manic focus on dodging extremely complex bullet patterns, where thousands of deadly projectiles can fill the screen at a time. The Touhou games are known for their intricate and complex bullet patterns, unique fantasy setting, many characters, and prodigal amount of fan-derived works...this card game included.

"This is a two-player turn-based dueling card game. Each player starts out by choosing four characters (repeats are allowed), and designates one as the leader. Your leader has an initial health point (HP), border value (BV) and evasion value (EV), which will be used throughout the match, as well as some special abilities. Your starting spell point (SP) is zero. The other characters are to allow you access to other cards; the character requirements can be seen at the top of each card.

After you've picked your team, you get to choose 40 cards (duplicates are allowed up to a total of three) that comprise your deck. Obviously you will pick cards that you can actually use.

You will keep track of your HP and SP using counters. The game ends when one person's leader's HP drops to zero or when his or her deck has been depleted."

One of the more interesting wargame designs coming out of Nazi Germany.

The game features 4 duplicate triangular maps of the field of battle that can be placed together to form a square board. Each section of the map contains 90 points with various obstacles that must be overcome (minefields, hedgehogs, wire fences) or repaired (blown bridges, destroyed roads). The playing pieces are metal miniatures (painted flats) consisting of German Sappers with various implements (explosives, wire cutters, Flame-thrower, etc.) and a tank.

The sappers move based on a die roll, in any combination the player desires. The object of the game is to overcome obstacles by gathering the right combination of sappers at the obstacle which is either then destroyed or repaired for the rest of the game. The final obstacle is a bunker that sits on the intersection of all four boards and must be destroyed to win the game.

boardgame.name: Blockade
Dennis Wheatley's Blockade
boardgame.description:
From the Rules: Blockade is played with multi-shaped wooden pieces representing Naval Formations, Air Units, Submarines and Cargo Ships on a six-color map. Victory consists of capturing or sinking all enemy Merchant Shipping so that the enemy is completely blockaded and cannot obtain further supplies from Neutral sources.

The Map shows four countries (two sets of paired enemies). The land war between them is considered to be locked in a Maginot Line type of stalemate so the battle hinges on the war at sea. The map has 32 ports (5 in each warring country and 12 on the coasts of the neutrals).

Each country has a different starting mix of units (for example Leoland is high in Naval Formations and Adlerreich has the most submarines). The player round consists of moving all your cargo ships 1 space then rolling the dice and moving your units. A player may make a single air attack instead of moving any naval units. The air units have unlimited range and the number required to make an attack is based on the target. Losses are also based on the target and are automatic (for example it takes 4 air units to attack a naval formation and 2 air units are automatically lost).

A merchant ship can join a naval formation and create a convoy for more protection. Naval combat consists of a surprise attack (by submarines) and open attacks between naval formations. The surprise attack can be triggered by a roll of 8 or higher and an open attack requires the player to spend 1 or 2 pips of the dice roll.

boardgame.description:
From the rules - Battle at Sea, the new game of National Defense, is played on a cloth surface which is marked with two sea lanes of 16 spaces each.

Players assume control of a fleet and moves his fleet through his respective sea lane attempting to sink as many ships of the enemy fleet as possible. When one fleet has been moved completely through its sea lane, the battle is over. The player who sinks the greatest amount of enemy tonnage is the winner.

Special embossed dice are used to determine hits. Gunnery ranges, destroyers laying smoke screens, and aircraft carriers allow for varied game play.

A very rare game of naval combat

boardgame.name: Conquest
boardgame.description:
From the rules: In brief the purpose of the game is to conquer as many of the 48 states shown on the map of the United States as possible.

Description from the rulebook:

Three hundred years ago the world powers were moving. Far off to the west a great unknown wilderness was opening up. North America was being conquered and empires were being built. Today in the game Conquest we re-enact the conquering of the continent.

It is a game in which keen judgement interspersed with dashes of bluff and audacity mingle with lady luck to create a game that on one is out of until the last hand is played.

The purpose of the game is to conquer as many of the 50 states shown as possible. States must be conquered in the order listed under "Order of Conquest" shown on the game board and are also one of either four colors and have a number associated with victory points at the end of the game.

There are four phases to the game - 1) Bidding your hand, 2)Marking of conquered territory and distribution of groups, 3)Dealing new cards, 4) Additional conquest.

In the bidding phase, players bid on their hand of five cards. First player is to the right of the dealer and then in subsequent hands, the winner of the previous hand starts the bid. Starting player places a bid. Bids cannot be higher than $5 million. The remaining players can either pass, meet the bid or raise the bid. Winning hands are determined in order of winning hierarchy: Single: Highest single card of color called for; Doubles: Two matching number cards, one in the color being called; Triples: Three matching number cards, one in the color being called; Sweep: All four cards of the same number.

In the second phase, the winner of the hand takes all money bid and places one of their markers on the state or states conquered, receiving the number of regiments of troops as indicated on the conquered state. 5 regiments = 1 division. Only divisions can be placed on the maps in any territories the players owns. Players may redistribute any troops that he possesses for the purposes of defense or offense. Players can also purchase additional troops.

In the third phase, the dealers asks if everyone is ready for the deal. The dealer hands out enough cards to bring all players hands up to five cards. If a player receives a money card they can immediately turn the card in to collect the cash and gets another card.

In the final phase, players may conquer states of their opponents. Starting with the player who won the last hand states can be conquered via the following rules: 1)State must adjoin the territory of conqueror and belong to an opponent 2) Must have more troop divisions that place being conquered 3) Player must pay bank sum of 10 million plus 5 million for every divsion that opponent has in the conquered territory (Max 40 million) 4) Only one state can be conquered per hand 5) Conquered troops are returned to opponent and 6) if conquests results in a complete territory being possessed than additional troops are obtained for the district.

To conclude the game: After all states have been conquered there is a final phase of general conquest until no one has any resources left to conquer with. The winner is the player having the highest score by totaling the victory points associated with the states conquered.

boardgame.name: G.H.Q.
GHQ
boardgame.description:
From the rules: G.H.Q. is a Strategic war game for two players, one player representing the Allied Armies and the other the German Army. The theater of War is the Western Front and the territories of countries adjacent to that front. The Object is to occupy ONE of two capital cities of the opponent.

On the map the principal towns are shown as red circles and connected together by thick red lines which represent the road and railway systems. Towns with black centers are Corps garrison towns and the associated units are marked on the map. The units (armoured, motorized and infantry corp) are represented by different shaped wooden pieces with Flags attached.

The Germans always go first and movement is governed by a roll of the dice. The roll will be between 1 and 3 and the number thrown indicates the number of units which may be moved. Armoured corps can move 3 spaces, Motorized 2 and Infantry 1 space. Destruction of units is based on having units adjacent to the target enemy, 3 friendly units are required to kill an armoured unit, infantry and motorized are destroyed by two friendly units in adjacent towns. For every enemy unit destroyed the player gets another roll.

boardgame.name: Diplomacy
The H. V. Kaltenborn Game of Diplomacy
H. V. Kaltenborn's Diplomacy
boardgame.description:
The goal of the game is to be the Diplomat that creates the Greatest World Empire by controlling strategic location cards, collecting Colony and Independent Country Flag cards, capturing soldiers, battleships and bombers.

The map consists of a circle of spaces with flags representing various countries of the world, across the center of the circle is the Bridge of Flags representing the six great colonizing countries. At the beginning of the game players pick one of the six great countries as their home country. They get one Diplomat, 10 consulates, 5 soldiers, 1 bomber and 1 battleship. The battleship and bomber are placed on the home country flag and all the diplomats are placed on "Start".

The mechanic of the game consists of movement around the path of flags via the roll of dice (doubles get a second roll). When a player lands on a colony he places a soldier, a second landing on the same colony gains a consulate and the Country Flag card. Landing on an independent country gains an immediate colony. Soldiers can be captured if another player lands on a colony before a consulate is placed. Players can move across the Bridge of Flags if they land on one of the two Neutral Countries, doing so gains the player a battleship or bomber. The battleship or bomber can be used to gain a strategic location flag if he owned when he lands on a strategic location. Normally players can only move clockwise but control of a strategic location allows the player to move either direction when he lands on one. Additional game play is added via card play introduced by landing on an "Isolation" spot.

The game ends when one player has placed 10 consulates. Flags, and captured tokens are worth points and the player with the most points at the end wins the game.

boardgame.name: Conquering Hollywood
boardgame.description:
Conquering Hollywood is the first board game about what it is really like to be in California making your dream of success in the movie business a reality. It's also the first game with "Personality Power," a way to compete with other players outside of the game itself ... that counts in the game.

The game of Conquering Hollywood is based on "Personality Power." That means everything you say and everything you do counts in the game. Even things you say and do "outside the game."

Conquering Hollywood is a cutthroat look at the true ways and means of Tinseltown. Actors! Producers! Directors! Writers! Just a Nobody? Get a car and pick up a screenplay. Compete with other players to make hit movies. Whether you're a nobody or a player, everyone in Tinseltown wants to be King of Hollywood! But there is only one King and his joy lasts only 15 minutes after an intense, hand-to-hand battle. To succeed at the game of Conquering Hollywood, you have to compete with the same people who used to be your friends. You have to compete all the time without losing concentration for a second. Compete for what? For possession of the things you need to make hit movies.

To "make it" in the movie biz in this game you need the following items: story, game, money, talent, style, vision, fight, grind, luck, call, wires, and looks.

boardgame.name: The Game of 5th Column Spy Hunters
boardgame.description:
To quote the rules: "Every 5th Columnist Spy that is caught pays the full penalty for his crime whether this country is at peace or at war. For a while a 5th Columnist spy may escape detection and cause much damage and many heartaches… but from the days of old... No 5th Columnist Spy has yet escaped." Excerpted from the rules section A Word About Spies by James Boyle - Former Special Investigator.

5th Column Spy Hunter is a point to point movement game for 2 teams. Players act as either the 5th Columnists or the Spy Hunters and move around a map of the United States based on Official Number Code from the Decoder (a spinner). The spinner provides moves based on a separate "code" list for 5th Columnists and Spy Hunters. 5th Columnists score points for ending their moves on designated spots (for example: air naval or army bases to steal documents), the Spy Hunters get points based on failures by the 5th Columnists. The winner is the first team to 15 points. Both teams are expected to record their routes so that a second game can be played to crown the "Champion Spy Hunter". The teams exchange routes and take turns listing the order of the states they entered and their capitols. Points are awarded for correct answers. Mistakes cost a team their turn. The Champion is the team with the highest score.

Speak It Not is an LDS game in which players attempt to reveal mystery words without using words that are not allowed. It is similar to the games Password and Taboo.

From the publisher: Speak It Not is an exciting, fast-paced card game for Latter-day Saints. Players divide into teams and take turns describing a mystery word without using that word or five other "forbidden" words listed on the drawn card. Capt'n Sharky: Pirate scrap
Capt'n Sharky: Piraten-Rauferei
Capt'n Sharky: Piratengevecht
Ghosts
Spirits!
boardgame.description:
In Ghosts — which was first released under the title Spirits! — players have a hand of five ghost cards (with values from 1 to 3 in six suits), and on a turn you play a card, then draw a card. Keep a running a tally of the sum of cards played. If you play a card of the same suit as the topmost played card, you keep the sum the same and reverse the order of play. You cannot bring the sum above 7, and if you cannot play or choose not to play, remove all the played cards, take a ghost marker, then play a card to start a new pile. When all the cards have been played, the round ends; shuffle the cards and deal a new hand of five cards to each player. If a player collects no ghosts in either the second or third round, they discard three ghost markers from their collection.

Whoever has the fewest ghost markers at the end of three rounds wins.

boardgame.name: Mijn Huis
My House
boardgame.description:
Taken from the Opstelten Speelgoed website.

Where are the toothbrushes to be found at your house? Do they belong in the kitchen, the bathroom or maybe in both? And what about your toys? Do they belong in the Living room or in your bedroom? In any case not in the bathroom. Then they better be stored in the attic. With the game My House children can playfully tell how things are organized at their home. It’s all about telling about their experiences from home. Becoming aware of the arrangement of things at home and thus familiar in their own house.

It is interesting and fun to hear for the parents, hearing their children talk about how they think about the arrangements at home. The children for their part become very resourceful in substantiating their ideas about the location of the objects. But My House offers even more. The older children can play memory games with it or call forth all their linguistic skills in a game of “Linguistic Happy Families”. Thus the game co-develops along with the development of the linguistic skills of the child. Ranging from story telling up to in their own words finding synonyms to complete their set of “Happy Families”!

From the Opstelten Speelgoed website:

The story starts hundreds of years ago. The oceans and seas are controlled by pirates. This is also the case in this game. Beware, or pirates will steel your gold coins, even before you have made your first move towards finding the treasure of Lame Max, the notorious pirate king of ancient times. It is your goal to retrieve most of Max’s treasure and become the next Pirate king.

The different game variants are constructed in such a way that the game follows the development stages of the children in the period between ages 3 and 9, for children interested in board games a crucial time. Whereas the younger players depend on a simple game structure and a relatively short playing time, they gradually develop towards a stage where they will want to have control over the game development, their progress as well as that of their opponents. In fact they desire that their own strategic insight can make the difference between winning or losing. In the most elaborate game variant the Pirate game is a challenge even for grown ups!

boardgame.name: Sandy Hawley's Post Time
boardgame.description:
A Canadian-made horse racing game, endorsed by champion jockey Sandy Hawley.

Game summary;
The players each start the game with the same amount of game money with which they buy horses and bet on them in 6 races. The horse cards are dealt to the players and each player decides to buy one or more of those dealt. Horses not purchased are returned to the bank and are offered again after the first race. The odds paid to the winning bet are determined by dealing the "odds" cards to the players' horses. Each player may bet up to $1000 to win on horses that the player owns. A race consists of 4 or 5 quarters. There are 5 identical decks of "race cards" that have on their face one of the ten available horses. For each of the quarters a "Race Card" deck is shuffled and then laid out in a row on the game board, the horse pictured on the last card is in the lead of that quarter. The leading horse earns a bonus for the player. The horse pictured on the last card of the last deck is the race winner. The winning horse earns the bet times the odds for the player. After 6 races, the horses are sold back to the bank for the original purchase price and the richest player is the game winner.

From the game box:
"The high stakes horse racing game. Fun for the whole family!
Post Time allows a maximum of 10 horses to run in every race.
Experience the thrill of owning a racehorse, entering it in a race, and collecting the prize money.
You have a six race series in which to accumulate assets, through buying horses and betting them to win! And, of course, your stable of winning horses can net you BIG purse money.
You don't need horseshoes to win!
A basic knowledge of horse racing is all you need to play and enjoy POST TIME. The Tote Board provided sets the odds, purse money and payoff for each race. Play your cards right, and you could be the 'winningest' owner at the track.
POST TIME includes:
1 Game Board
1 Tote Board
1 Set of Steward Cards
1 Set of ODDS Cards
1 Program with Rules
5 Sets of Race Cards
1 Set of Ownership Cards
POST TIME Cash"

boardgame.name: Qi Guo Xiang Qi
七囯象棋
boardgame.description:
This "variant" of Xiangqi is played on a 19 X 19 grid (Go board). Seven armies represent the seven warring states of the late Zhou Dynasty (1045 - 221 BC):
Qin (white), Chu (red), Qi (indigo), Yan (black), Han (orange), Wei (green), Zhao (purple).

Each army is played by one player. For less than 7 players, there are several predetermined "allies", so one or more players direct two armies.

Every army has 17 pieces, which makes a total of 120, regarding the central single piece, representing the kingdom of Zhou. This piece does not move at all and cannot be captured.

Each of the armies consist of the following pieces:
1 General - moving like the Queen in modern Western Chess.
1 Deputy General - moving like the Rook in modern Western Chess.
1 Officer - moving like the Bishop in modern Western Chess.
1 Diplomat - moving like the Queen, too, but cannot capture or be captured.
1 Cannon - like the Cannon in XiangQi (moving like the Rook, but capturing over one intervening piece).
1 (Unit of) Archers - moving like the Queen, but only for 4 spaces.
1 (Unit of) Crossbowmen - moving like the Queen, but only for 5 spaces
2 (Units of) Swordsmen - moving 1 space diagonally.
4 (Units of) Broadswordsmen - moving 1 space vertically or horizontally.
4 (Units of) Cavalry - moving 4 spaces: 1 in a straight line and then 3 diagonally.

There are several rules regulating possible allies and winning conditions over single states. Residual pieces of beaten armies are removed from the board.

Simplified, it can be said, that to gain a victory over another state, a player has to capture the general or more than 10 pieces of this state. The player with the most captured pieces at the end of the game wins.

There are similarities both to Go (the central piece as the centre of the universe/representing the Zhou Dynasty, or the removing of "dead" armies) and Xiangqi (the pieces, the armies ...); this and the 7 players make this game unique in the history of strategic boardgames.

From the rules:

Each player represents a country engaged in war. The players begin the game with well equipped sea, air, and land forces and a war chest. The units are moved around the board, encountering the dangers and obstacles of modern warfare. boardgame.name: Empires
boardgame.description:
Based on game play mechanics Empires seems to be the precursor to games like Risk.

From the rules:

Empires is played on a world map; the individual players representing "Powers" which include; the United States, Great Britain, France, Russia, Italy and Japan. The object is for one player to establish a World Empire and eliminate all other players from the game.

Parts include 6 pawns representing each country, 20 Markers for each player, 48 resource cards and 48 armament cards with values of 1 or 5 representing Air, Navy and Army units.

Players start in the start box and move from point to point around the world map, landing on free territories (gaining a resource card), colonies (placing a marker to control and taking resources) and blockades (if owned then 2 resources are owned to the controlling player). Resources can be converted into armaments, 3 resources for 1 randomly drawn armament. Once all colonies are taken a colonial war begins and as players land on opposing colonies they may choose an armament class and announce an attack. The player with the highest strength wins the battle and takes the colony. If he loses he loses resources equal to the colonies values.

The final stage is total war when all armaments are gone. The first player back to start challenges the other players to war and compares values for all armaments, winner take all. Last man standing wins.

boardgame.description:

Probably from the 1950s. A simple roll-and-move game where up to 5 players are mice (small pottery balls), trying to reach the end of a tilted course (with holes for spaces, similar to Hänsel und Gretel: Ein Märchenspiel), one player is the cat (a larger ball), allowed to move in both directions, trying to catch all mice.

The cat never can fall through the holes, the mice can (and have to start over).

The board is raised and has a track on it. Each point along the track is a hole. Some holes are bigger than others. The playing pieces are circular, like a ball.

One player is a cat, the others are mice. Everyone moves along the track by a die roll. The mice must escape from the cat player who has a big advantage. If a mouse player lands on one of the bigger holes then it will fall through the hole and out of the game. The cat playing ball is too large to fall through a hole so he doesn't mind which space he lands on.

The cat wins if all the mice are caught or the mouse who gets to the end of the track first, wins

boardgame.name: Bombers Aloft
boardgame.description:
From the rules:

There are four lanes of travel. The first spin selects the lane of travel. Player 1 spins again and sets the bomber's altitude. The nose of the bomber is placed in the metal stand provided at the height noted. A third spin gives the movement value.

The AA gun spins next (2 times to set the lane and altitude). If they match the lane and height of the bomber it is brought down. Each player follows in succession with a bomber and then the AA gun's attack. If the AA score a kill it gets points based on the zone the bomber is in and its altitude.

The lanes contain spaces with numbers (from 1 to 14) that reference the hit on the score card. The value is recorded as part of the score. Any plane that comes to a "Change Altitude" space spins the spinner for a new altitude.

The game ends when all bombers have been shot down or have reached the finish line. The player with the largest score is the winner.

From the game's designer:

'While I enjoy Star Fleet Battles, it seems that there has been so much added to it since I first played that it is not the game that I first played. I wanted a simple, flexible game - and I wanted to add in Construction - something never in SFB. So here we are.

boardgame.name: aka Yet Another Pirate Themed Board Game
Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard
boardgame.description:
Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard (aka Yet Another Pirate Themed Board Game) is based on the award-winning children's song of the same name by Eric Herman and Kenn Nesbitt. Eric Herman designed the game with the same core audience in mind as his music fans (elementary school kids and their parents).

Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard is a very lightly weighted and semi-abstract "race to get the most treasure", but it also incorporates some nice Eurogame touches, including action point movement, card combinations, minimal luck and variable victory point options. As such, it is an excellent gateway game for younger players on the verge of discovering more involved games like Settlers and Tikal.

The game is designed in the low-cost tradition of (James Ernest's company), with pennies, nickels and dimes used for treasures, and tokens from other games used as the game pieces, and with a great amount of humor in the cards.

Blackbeard, Bluebeard and Redbeard is currently in playtesting and is expected to be available in 2008.

There are 8 sets in the deck of 36 cards. The Double sets have "Bonus" points. When a player scores with a double, and connects the numbers, the player gets the regular points plus the bonus points.

All players must quote the scripture out loud before connecting the numbers. The first player to run out of cards must say, "Bible Knows". The one who wins the hand receives all points in the other players hand except the bonus points.

boardgame.name: Crapette
Crapot
Garibaldka
Russian Bank
Stop
Touch
boardgame.description:
Russian Bank -- also known as Crapette -- is a game played by two players with two standard decks of playing cards. Each player begins the game with a tableau four face up house cards, a 12 card reserve, and a "hand" consisting of the remainder of the cards. The first player to clear their tableau, reserve, and hand of cards onto the foundation spaces in the middle of the board is the winner. Although the rules of card placement and foundation building are similar to those of Klondike solitaire, Russian Bank allows equal access by both players to both layouts, thus adding player interaction.

Foundation spaces are built up in suit from ace to king. Houses are built down in alternating colors from king to ace.

Some moves in the game are compulsory:
-- if the top card of the reserve may be played to a foundation, that play must be made first.
-- if an available card in the houses can be played to the foundations, that play must be made.
-- if any house is empty, one must fill the space from the reserve if possible.
-- whenever the top card from the reserve is played, the next reserve card must be turned face up.

If none of the above moves are available, the player turns the top card of his hand face up and continues play. The player may play the card legally as any other card. Likewise, a player may play a cards to his opponent's waste pile if the card played matches in suit and is of a consecutive rank. Once a player has no more legal moves, his face-up hand it is discarded into the player's waste pile and his turn ends. If the hand is empty when the player needs to draw a hand card, the waste pile is turned face down to refresh the hand.

If at any time a player makes an illegal play or ignores an opportunity to make one of the compulsory plays, his opponent may stop him, point out the error, and force the proper play. The erring player then forfeits the remainder of that turn.

boardgame.name: War Tactics or Can Great Britain Be Invaded?
boardgame.description:
One of the oldest high level strategy games, War tactics takes place on a map containing England, Denmark, Belgium, Germany and a part of northern France.

The map is divided into a series of squares which include ports, forts towns, cities and the capitals. Units include land units, dreadnoughts, torpedo boats, cruisers, air units and subs. Each unit has a different movement pattern (for example ships - dreadnoughts, torpedo boats, cruisers all can move 1 square forward, right or left but not diagonal or backward) and the players try to capture enemy units and ultimately the enemy capital. Landing on an enemy will capture him.

Players take turns moving units and gain rewards for occupying key sites like naval bases and 1 square of the capital (out of a total of 4). Scores are gained for occupying towns, cities and naval bases. At the end of the game the player with the most points wins the game.

boardgame.name: Army Checkers
boardgame.description:
The object of the game is to capture one or more enemy men between two of your men. Captures may be made along vertical, diagonal or horizontal rows of squares.

On the first turn only, the opening player player places 2 men, 1 on the start in the center of the board and 1 more adjacent. The other player must then place 2 side by side, adjacent to the first player. Each player then places a single man next to an enemy man trying to encase them between friendly men. Any enemy so encased are flipped over to the friendly side.

When maneuvers end the player with the most men showing wins.

boardgame.name: All Fall Down
boardgame.description:
The exciting race game where players pieces may suddenly disappear with a "plonk".

The game board consists of two layers. The top layer has a race course with hole on each square surrounded by a plastic rim to hold upright the narrow player pawns. The bottom layer is on black card with various holes and sits inside the box. When the upper board is placed on top most squares on the race track have a solid footing for the pawns, but some have holes that allow the pawns to fall through into the box and out of the game. The boards are square so that they can be rotated in relation to each other to provide variable distribution of the holes.

Each player takes 5 pawns. The winner is the first person to get a pawn to the end of the track. Players roll the dice and move one of their pawns the distance indicated. If they have multiple pawns on the track they can chose which one to move. When a hole is discovered by a player losing their piece to it all players need to remember where it is so that they don't repeat the mistake.
